reviewText: Well, it really is interesting, especially if you ever wondered how these guys manage to do what they do. We all knew there was more to it than guys in dark shades walking near the president and looking like something out of a rather corny spy story. And there is, there surely is. As this was done in 2004, the two main people on whom the descriptions focused were Bush and Kerry. Because as most people know, ever since Bobby Kennedy was assassinated, presidential candidates also have Secret Service protection. After watching the detailed work involved in preparing for a single presidential appearance, I found myself sort of wishing that in Bush's case, they had not been quite so careful. Then I thought about Dick Cheney, and got all cold. Yeah, I'm glad they are so incredibly good at their job.They send a team to prepare a site a week in advance, and so of course there must be several advance teams working at any given time. They have to coordinate with state and local law enforcement at the location, and they have extremely sophisticated support staff. We get to see a lot, even though clearly some things must be kept secret. For example, every single threat on the president's life, no matter how trivial, must be investigated. A written threat is analyzed not only for fingerprints, the origins of the ink and the paper, but for traces of DNA in the fingerprints. Recorded threats (by phone or mailed in audio media) are analyzed for voice recognition and all sorts of nuances that may link it to some earlier threat or anything in the government's vast crime data base. One agent described it as like CSI without commercial breaks.Among the agents interviewed were ones that had been on the scene at various key moments in Secret Service history. Remember the agent that jumped onto the bumper of the President's car when Kennedy was shot? He's an old man now, of course, but he was interviewed, and gave some horribly graphic details about what he saw that day. He eventually had to leave the service because of the PTSD involved in that experience. The two Manson family attempts on President Ford, the day Reagan was shot, and a near miss involving President Clinton are also detailed by those who were there.It may not be a report of interest to all, but I found it fascinating. The only reason I give it only three stars is that the narration was a bit wooden, and the whole thing was almost 100% favorable to the Service. I can't help thinking there should have been a little more look at the dark side. These people are trained to a fair-thee-well, and the stress of the job is certainly major, but I thought the gratuitous comments about how they will not get rich once they leave the service, but just become ordinary citizens, was a bit disingenuous. Surely they go on to good careers in private security services, and very possibly services like Blackwater and the like. Or perhaps join city or state police service, or training. They are not simply relegated to the unemployment office.
summary: Only Some of Their Secrets, of Course

reviewText: Well this wasn't an easy topic to do reseach on.Well,you could tell that because of the name "Secret Service." National Geogrphics was allowed access to a alot of interesting things.The secret service has always facinated me.There whole operation are here in full detail.How they perpare a sight weeks in advance for the president.It shows all the assassinations and  assassination attempts that were caught on camera.I really like the pace of this documentary.One of the best narrarated National Geographic has really done a terrific job.Compared to the Inside the F.B.I Doc,I would say that this is alot better in detail,pace,length.If you are interested in this topic you should buy this.It also contains two 20 minute documentary on x-presidents.I highly recommend this. reviewText: The U.S. Secret Service is an integral part of our democratic system of government.  The American people vote to elect particular candidates, and it is the Secret Services' duty to ensure that these individuals are able to do the duty they were elected to perform.  This video includes a lot of recent and historical information, including Secret Service agents from the Kennedy, Ford, Clinton, and Bush I and Bush II administrations.Secret Service agents are very professional and structured individuals.  Everyday they take actions to protect our democracy from foreign and domestic threats, and we all should be grateful for their patriotic service.  This documentary is quite exciting.Michael Gordon
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The U.S. Secret Service is best known for guarding the President of the United States. Most of us have seen the agents in dark glasses shadowing the President, scanning the surroundings for any possible threats.But few people may know that the U.S. Secret Service was created to combat counterfeiting. And it may come as a surprise that half of the Secret Service staff today is dedicated to investigating counterfeit currency."It's the government agency that's always been shrouded in secrecy-it's the U.S. Secret Service. Now, the National Geographic Channel brings it to DVD to give you unprecedented access into this first and last line of defense for the president.Inside The US Secret Service premiered on the National Geographic Channel on October the 24th. This documentary which showcases the US Secret Service agency tells us all we ever wanted to know about what they do... Such as the stuff they go through during training as well as their investigations on counterfeit currency and what it takes to protect the President of the United States..This is a must have on DVD... 2 Thumbs Up!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: While I think this dvd is highly entertaining and informative, and while I also think the layman out there will truly enjoy it, for the very well informed like myself (I am the leading civilian authority on the Secret Service, especially with regard to the period from FDR to Reagan), I have some mixed emotions. For one, like the 1995 History Channel and 1995 Discovery Channel documentaries (both available only on vhs), this was an officially-sanctioned production, so, needless to say, trade secrets and controversy are kept to a bare minimum, to put it mildly. Second, while Clint Hill appears on all 3 productions, I feel even more could have been said by him about not only the events of 11/22/63, but with regard to the JFK/ LBJ years, in general (he DOES state that the back of the head behind the right ear was gone, thus corroborating his own 1963 SS report and 1964 WC testimony; it's good to hear him actually say the words). In addition, as with the Discovery Channel production (and the 1996 PBS special re: Truman), former ASAIC/ #2 agent under JFK Floyd M. Boring makes a noteworthy appearance, but, as with his other two appearances, only to deal with the infamous 11/1/50 Blair House assassination attempt on President Truman; nothing about his role as planner of the Texas trip and so forth.In addition to the "usual suspects" (Hill, Boring, Jerry Parr), it would have been nice to seem some new faces like Joe Petro (with a book out right now) and Robert DeProspero (SAIC during part of the Reagan years, between Parr and Shaddick).Still, for 90-99% of the viewing audience, you will find much to like about this documentary, arguably the best of the 3, although I feel the 1995 History Channel documentary is the best for the early days of the Secret Service. For the JFK years, please read "Murder In Dealey Plaza" by Fetzer and "The Secret Service" by Melanson, as well as "Survivor's Guilt: The Secret Service & The Failure To Protect The President" by yours truly, due out soon.

reviewText: Very interesting documentary of the elusive US Secret Service and its work. Insightful, objective and factual; kudos to the production team, research and the men for sharing! Well done! Thank you!
